stream_context.summary: Kaze live-blocked out the new Ice Castle (Course unknown) for Return to Yoshi’s Island, focusing on pure platform layout—mainly slides, wind, mirror-wall wall-kicks and warp connections—before any final art pass.

development_findings.summary: The team’s workflow is strictly ‘platforming first, visuals second’; Kaze will not polish graphics until movement feels right.
development_findings.quote: Our task for the day is to make the platforming good and then after we made the platforming good we can make the visuals good.

development_findings.summary: Ice Castle is conceived as a momentum-heavy slide playground with optional risky shortcuts, vanilla-SM64 difficulty but aided by Kaze’s tighter controls.
development_findings.quote: Some of this may look more difficult, but the controls in this game are a lot more consistent, so that hopefully makes up for the difficulty.

development_findings.summary: Castle loops back on itself via warp pipes and slide tubes in place of space-hungry walkways, freeing geometry budget and aiding flow.
A mirror wall section will let players wall-kick against their reflection; memory limits force only one mirrored side to avoid ‘hall-of-mirrors’ overdraw.
development_findings.quote: I'm on an N64. Do you really want that?

development_findings.summary: Window tiles now blow wind; Kaze is adding a lower speed cap so long-jumps aren’t over-boosted.
Bottomless-pit texture now uses Biobak’s black-alpha noise idea plus TexGen scroll, giving a fiery void effect Kaze calls “insane”.
development_findings.quote: Oh my God, this looks insane.

development_findings.summary: Star plan locked in: 1) glass-caged star shown early, 2) snowman cave slide, 3) big raven boss atop castle, 4) cold-haze basement star, 5) reds outside, 6) secret 8-bit pipe hidden in an ‘ice jail’ cell.
Kaze keeps ROM under 64 MB to stay authentic to original hardware; source code will release only after launch to avoid spoilers.
development_findings.quote: If I release it before then I dig my whole mod… the source code release is a hundred percent planned.

development_findings.summary: Considering ML upscaling (DLSS/FSR) from 160×120 to full res on real N64 as future experiment.
development_findings.quote: Imagine you just have an option to turn DLSS on or off in your Mario 64 hack.

development_findings.summary: Camera in tight indoor rooms is a major unresolved problem; options include hard-corner lock or deleting rooms to widen space.

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy: game should scale in difficulty with player bravery; freedom > forced challenge.
context_findings.quote: The game is as difficult as you are brave, and if you're just not brave… that’s on you.

context_findings.summary: Kaze avoids praising AI publicly for fear of Twitter backlash.
context_findings.quote: I'm at a point where I won't say that anything AI is going to look cool publicly because I think that I will literally be murdered on twitter.com.

context_findings.summary: He lives frugally, flips cartridges for income, and only spends on tools that recoup money.
context_findings.quote: I did make the Waluigi’s Tango Stand cartridge, which netted me $600, so honestly the RetroBlaster thing was a plus $400 for me.

context_findings.summary: Currently also contracted on an Unreal Engine 5 project for another company.
Shows mild streaming stress—balancing chat, multi-platform restream failures, and active level editing.

biobak.summary: Proposed multi-texture ice shader math (shade color + prim color) and supplied void texture concept that Kaze implemented.
biobak.quote: We must combine it as multi-texture plus shade color plus prim color over shade alpha.

biobak.summary: Suggested black-alpha noise for voids which led to the new bottomless-pit effect.

key_stories.title: Mirror-Wall Brainstorm
key_stories.summary: Chat pitched mirrored corridors; Kaze loved the style but realized full mirrors would tank performance. He negotiated a compromise: one mirrored wall used for repeated wall-kicks.
key_stories.challenge: Create a striking ice-mirror mechanic without overloading N64 rendering.
key_stories.process: Discussed hall-of-mirrors risk, tested layout, limited to single reflective plane.
key_stories.outcome: Feature kept, but only one side will reflect; section now on level map.
key_stories.key_quote: Do you really want that? I'm on an N64.

key_stories.title: Bottomless Pit Visual Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Biobak dropped a void-texture idea; Kaze implemented a shifting black-alpha noise and found it unexpectedly gorgeous.
key_stories.process: Tested texture with TexGen scroll, tweaked opacity, live-previewed in engine.
key_stories.outcome: Effect adopted for voids and maybe slides; opens visual identity for castle.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my God, this looks insane.

key_stories.title: Slide Hack Side-Project with Eiza
key_stories.summary: Kaze released a mini slide hack the same day; he did all programming and slide layout while artist Eiza handled models and shaders.
key_stories.challenge: Build a polished one-star hack quickly as a palette cleanser.
key_stories.process: One-week dev sprint; back-and-forth with Eiza on models; Kaze focused on water visibility and smooth slides.
key_stories.outcome: Hack published, praised for controls; served as test-bed for RTYI slide feel.
key_stories.key_quote: I did all the programming and I helped them with a bunch of shaders… Eiza did most of his own stuff himself.
